thread.title: Tara Palmer-Tomkinson’s funeral takes place nearly three weeks after her death
thread.title_full: Tara Palmer-Tomkinson’s funeral takes place nearly three weeks after her death - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: Tara Palmer-Tomkinson’s funeral takes place nearly three weeks after her death
text:
Tara Palmer-Tomkinson’s funeral takes place nearly three weeks after her death The socialite was laid to rest today   Share By Jessica Gibb 17:18, 27 FEB 2017 Celebs Tara Palmer-Tomkinson (Photo: AFP)   Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email Tara Palmer-Tomkinson ’s funeral took place today. 
It was attended only by family and close friends – at the request of her family.
The 45 year old died of a perforated ulcer on 8 February, and not of a brain tumour, as was previously thought.
Last week, Westminster Coroner's Court decided not to go ahead with an inquest into her death after a post mortem examination found the former It-girl died of natural causes.
Read More Coroner will 'not hold inquest' into death of former It girl Tara Palmer-Tomkinson Tara Palmer-Tomkinson's funeral was held today (Photo: PA) The former It-girl passed away just months after revealing she had been diagnosed with a growth on her pituitary gland.
In a statement released on 16 February, her sister Santa Montefiore said: “I’ve been so touched by the warm response to Tara’s death.
"Thank you from the whole family. But I’d like to clarify a couple of points.
Read More Tara Palmer-Tomkinson was NOT in a 'dark place' in the weeks before her death Tara and her sister Santa Sebag Montefiore (Photo: Rex Features) “Today the coroner’s report states that Tara died of natural causes – a perforated ulcer.
"She did not have a brain tumour.”
The family added in a statement that Tara had passed away peacefully in her sleep at home in Kensington, West London.
Tara said in an interview in November that she was diagnosed last January and had treatment.
Tara died of natural causes (Photo: Getty) She added: “My growth was nonmalignant but it affected the production of prolactin [a hormone].
"Thankfully, it seems to have gone away for now.”
Santa told the Mirror it was “correct” that Tara had never had a brain tumour but instead had a pituitary tumour.
The pituitary is in close proximity to the brain, but it is not part of the brain.
